After hopscotching across the Caribbean, Venezuelan gold is landing in world-class refineries thousands of miles away. The refineries are inadvertently laundering ‘blood gold’ while obscuring the devastation surrounding its origins. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2YaGWRN

The private and commercial planes flying over sunburned tourists have been dropping off thousands of pounds of Venezuelan gold, according to airport operators, customs officials and government sources. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/30QLfDy

It’s hard to fully grasp the scope of Venezuela’s gold trade. Less than 50 miles away from Venezuela, the shiny Caribbean beaches of Curaçao and Aruba have become much more than tourist destinations. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/7r0H4gQsAE

A 2017 study found that communities living along Colombia’s Atabapo, Guainía and Inírida rivers, near the Venezuelan mines, had about 60 times the maximum safe level of mercury recommended by the World Health Organization. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2SvvEX2

South America’s indigenous people also aren’t spared. Illegal gold mining is destroying the rainforest, and toxic mercury — used to bind gold flakes — is poisoning the region’s water supply. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/vL1EdXPHwu
Trying to evade those tolls can be deadly. ‘If they want to collect, you pay or die,’ said a former Venezuelan soldier who now smuggles gold. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2Yd57ii
Many refugees end up having to smuggle gold, bribing their way through National Guard and guerrilla checkpoints to get the metal to the Colombian border. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/XQydWhbls6

It’s not just the military. Venezuelan crime syndicates and Colombian armed groups also have their hands in the illegal gold trade. For those trying to escape Maduro’s rule, the groups have one thing in common: They make the journey out of Venezuela dangerous. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/EjvPjxpll2
“The military arrived to do business, not to protect the citizens. Every week there is a murder,” one businessman said. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2Yc47Lp

American consumers are unwitting players in a vicious game. Organized crime groups and members of Maduro’s National Guard have taken over villages and turned them into gold mining hells, exploiting workers and killing residents with impunity. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/btMK7dAMdB

America’s demand for the precious metal is helping fuel Venezuela’s illegal gold mining trade. Venezuela’s ‘blood gold’ is being smuggled, and Miami, the center of the anti-Maduro movement, sits at the very heart of the scheme. #SmugglersParadisehttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article230669164.html …

Why is Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro still in power? The country’s oil industry has collapsed, his people are starving and his government is increasingly isolated. But Maduro has one cash cow left: Gold. (THREAD) #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/5Rk9fLtSmC

And check out our #PricedOutofParadise series on Miami's growing housing crisis:https://hrld.us/2XfblOs
Read the full story here:https://hrld.us/2Xnm4Xe

“This kind of innovative housing solution will be the only way to solve the housing affordability crisis that we are currently facing,” said Albert Milo, president of Related Urban Development Group, which partnered with Miami-Dade County on the project.

When the final three phases are finished by 2023, the $300M Liberty Square development will house a total of 1,455 units of all price ranges, from public housing to market rate. Six blocks of the site have been rezoned to allow for commercial components such as a Publix.

Then came Saturday, when Gregory was handed the key to her one-bedroom apartment in the new Liberty Square. When she opened the door and saw the polished floors and shiny appliances, she burst into tears. Her rent remains the same as it was before — $147 per month.pic.twitter.com/I9oQhApEMP

So when developers came around 2 years ago with plans to replace the dilapidated homes of Liberty Square with new apartments, she didn’t believe them. “I knew they were not going to build anything like that for us. We’re public housing. They don’t do that for us.”

Liberty Square resident Sharon Gregory was skeptical. She had lived in a public housing unit for 17 years, tired and scared of the violence that has plagued one of the oldest housing projects in the U.S. (THREAD) https://hrld.us/2J3CZdk pic.twitter.com/5eEF5bDc5s

Activist Gail Colleta has asked lawmakers to consider lifting residency restrictions if an offender is a certain age or has ailments. “This is a humanity issue. … We’re more concerned about stray animals than we are about people with issues, that need to have medication.”

In Florida, counties and cities have different rules limiting where offenders can live. Miami-Dade and Broward counties are considered among the most restrictive. Both have a 2,500-foot residency restriction, which is less than half a mile.pic.twitter.com/4a4AtbNFeh
Sex offenders remain on the registry for life, meaning a young offender will continue to face the same restrictions in his or her senior years.

The problem is sparking a national crisis: How and where do we allow the most-reviled class of citizens to survive their silver years after they have served their prison terms, while striving to protect children?
People on Florida’s list of 73,000 registered offenders who are 65 and older are increasing, according to state data. Currently, Florida’s registry has about 10,200 elderly offenders.

Mark Sullivan found his 94-year-old roommate, Aquila “Bud” Albertson, grasping onto their refrigerator in pain. Albertson needed help. But they knew he wasn’t going to get the care he needed. Albertson died. Both men are registered sex offenders. (THREAD)https://hrld.us/2L1QPON

“There’s no doubt that there’s a direct link between the violence and the closing of La Pampa,” Madre de Dios Gov. Luís Hidalgo Okimura said.pic.twitter.com/5kxt4qsIeR

In April, a tourist bus was held up at gunpoint near Madre de Dios’ capital, Puerto Maldonado, and in February, a nature lodge, full of Japanese sightseers, was robbed and one of the workers was murdered.
The result? A $69 million hole in Peru's economy ⁠— and a spike in crime that's bleeding into other parts of the country, affecting tourism.
So Peru's government shut down the gold fields. In the process, it also unveiled just how addicted the region had become to illegal mining.
The 40-square-mile area, known as La Pampa, used to be old-growth Amazon forest. Now, it's a toxic wasteland.pic.twitter.com/Cq9yVShLzq

. @NBPSEagles student Stacey Gringauz's nonprofit has raised $180,000 for charity. Yang also brought two Chinese-born tech executives to take $50k photos with Trump at a December 2017 RNC fundraiser. Neither paid for their seat directly. Reimbursing anyone for a ticket without full-disclosure would be illegal. So who paid?https://hrld.us/2YR4qNd
For example, a leader from the foreign arm of the Communist Party of China attended one of Yang’s Mar-a-Lago galas in 2018.https://hrld.us/2U38rzF

Yang has been making a name for herself by promoting her galas, selling them as opportunities for Chinese businessmen to gain face time with the Trump family. Lee bundled them into travel diplomacy packages sold in China. A breakdown of how that worked:https://hrld.us/2YD6ND8
Here's how Lee and Yang coordinate, as first reported by our team:pic.twitter.com/hjnXQFXei6

She also said she had been invited by a friend "Charles" – a known associate of Yang's in peddling access to Trump. Charles Lee claims to be both a prince and a member of a U.N. association. Neither appear true.

The woman arrested with malware was headed to an event advertised on Chinese social media by Yang. She said she wanted to use the club's pool, then said she wanted to discuss U.S.-China economic relations with a member of Trump's family, court records say.https://hrld.us/2YTduBx
We've been following these developments for the past few weeks. How are they all connected? Here’s what we know:
The investigation has also recently focused on Cindy Yang, sources tell us. She's the massage parlor entrepreneur-turned-Republican fundraising event promoter.

On Saturday, the probe took on higher urgency after Secret Service agents arrested a Chinese woman who tried to enter Mar-a-Lago with a thumb drive loaded with "malicious malware," plus four cellphones, an external hard-drive and a laptop.
That investigation has been going on for at least several months. It focused on Chinese nationals doing business in South Florida while potentially gathering intelligence for China's government.

So, how did Nibbs stay at the school for so long? @colleen_wright looked at how two powerful institutions — the United Teachers of Dade and Miami-Dade County Public Schools — dealt with 12 years of allegations against the veteran educator.https://hrld.us/2TxORpM
While his students filed complaint after complaint against him, Nibbs rose into the teachers union’s inner circle.

The girls who complained about Nibbs were already vulnerable. They were often in trouble, struggled academically and were overage for their grade. Many of them were bullied, and Nibbs is said to have comforted them and given them food.
The first complaint came in May 2004 when a 14-year-old girl told an assistant principal that Nibbs pulled her toward him and told her, "One day you’re going to be mine," while rubbing her waist.

Nibbs had already faced five allegations of sexual misconduct before he was arrested. That’s a total of nine students accusing the teacher of inappropriate behavior in the 15 years since he became a teacher.

This confused voters, and even caused Gov. Rick Scott to flip out after 60,000 additional votes were counted in left-leaning South Florida after election night.
4. Lack of transparency: Days after the election, the state couldn't explain how many votes had been rejected or even how many votes remained to be counted.

3. Old technology: Election officials have shied away from high-tech voting methods. It's almost taboo in an era of Russian hacking fears. But new hardware, software and databases exist that could make supervisors' lives easier. We look at some here:https://hrld.us/2SyFp5g
But bad ballot design is not a problem unique to Florida. There are really simple fixes we could learn from other states, like strengthening standards and implementing ballot-design review.

Some argue that shifting to a completely mail-based system would save Florida money and avoid future chaos as voting by mail inevitably becomes more popular.

Voting by mail is incredibly popular. But experts say Florida will reach a tipping point where the time and effort to process those mail ballots will grow, and officials won't have enough time to count them all within the state's extremely tight deadlines.pic.twitter.com/3RfDyaTndu

In order to track 365 days of gun-related deaths #SinceParkland, @McClatchy and @teamtrace pulled data from @GunDeaths and compiled a database of law enforcement media and records contacts to request reports from more than 600 agencies.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224957145.html …

Although Parkland seemed certain to change the parameters of the gun debate in America, 2018 looked a lot like 1929, when Americans were shocked and appalled by the St. Valentine’s Day Massacre, yet did little to alter their country’s gun law.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224594280.html …

But no city, relative to its size, has been so scarred by gun violence as Delaware’s biggest city, Wilmington. It was dubbed “The Most Dangerous Place in America for Youth.”https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article226090070.html …

In Florida alone, there have been about 80 gun deaths — including the Parkland students — of youths 18 and under in the year #SinceParklandhttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/state/florida/article224898685.html …

#SinceParkland, more than 130 children were shot and killed in domestic situations — the vast majority being murder-suicides.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224983580.html …

#SinceParkland, at least 150 children have died in accidental shootings. But do careless gun owners go to jail when their kids shoot themselves? Not always.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article225006255.html …
Most of these young people were not shot at school, but at home, on the street, with friends, or while riding bicycles. For example…

On the week of the anniversary of the #Parkland massacre, @teamtrace is publishing those portraits and @MiamiHerald and @McClatchy are presenting a series of stories on the year in gun violence against children. https://sinceparkland.org/about #SinceParkland

. @teamtrace wanted to acknowledge those lost lives. It assembled a team of more than 200 journalists — kids themselves — to research and write short portraits of every victim, 18 and under, for that 365-day period. https://sinceparkland.org/ #SinceParkland

That means that #SinceParkland, the United States have had enough young gun victims to fill three ultra-wide Boeing 777s, and the true number is certainly higher because no government agency keeps a real-time tally.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224680840.html …

After the shooting of 14 students and three adults at a Florida high school by a former student, parents and students rallied to say: Never again. “That time was revealing for me. I got squeezed,” Winslow said of that two-year period. “You squeeze a fruit or food or anything, you’re going to see what it’s made out of. I think the good times, the bad times that filled those years, they revealed the kind of person I am."pic.twitter.com/acQtprqEE0

Winslow returned to Miami for his fourth NBA season as a happier and more confident person. His improvement has been one of the most encouraging developments of a season that has the Heat in eighth place in the East.pic.twitter.com/99qmkQLPKW

For Winslow, it was his peers who inspired him to open up about his mental struggles. Mental health issues have been a topic of conversation around the NBA after stars like DeMar DeRozan and Kevin Love revealed stories about their own mental health battle.pic.twitter.com/s7H28aDfsa

“He doesn’t want to tell us because he doesn’t want us to worry,” his mom said. “But we can tell. You’re the baby of the family. We know when there’s something bothering you. We know what’s going on. It was a really dark time, especially when he had that surgery on his shoulder."
As the youngest of four, it was obvious to those around Winslow there was something weighing him down. Even when he remained quiet about the issues he was facing, they knew.

There was plenty of empathy from Winslow’s family and friends, though. But there was no intervention. There was only an open line of communication they made sure Winslow knew was there whenever he needed to talk about things.pic.twitter.com/vyICgiOloK
"There were times where it would be 3, 4 in the morning and I would just stay up until we went to breakfast the next morning and made sure he got to practice,” Rhodes said.

Derek Rhodes, who met and became close friends with Winslow while both attended Duke, lived with him during this two-year period. From quiet postgame dinners to sleepless nights to emotional conversations, it didn’t take long for Derek to realize something was off with Winslow.pic.twitter.com/YJYkL164Zb
“There were times when I didn’t know my place in this league or if I had a place or if I should go to the G League,” Winslow said.

This period in Winslow’s life began in the middle of 2016-17 when he suffered a shoulder injury that required surgery and cut his second NBA season short after just 18 games. And it continued in 2017-18 when his third NBA season didn’t live up to outside expectations.pic.twitter.com/0Wo00j1czC
His oldest brother described the previous two seasons as a “storm” and his mother called it “a really dark time” in Winslow’s life.

Now, residents say, Arctic has become collateral damage in a vicious political feud between a heavy-handed mayor/manager duo and the former police chief. Read the full story:https://hrld.us/2QkG74Y

Arctic’s handler was a 20-year-veteran of the village police department and served as acting chief. But she had a falling out with the mayor and her right hand, the village manager. Open hostilities between them broke out.
When asked about Arctic's abrupt dismissal, the village manager said his gig with police never officially existed. But emails obtained by the @MiamiHerald indicate otherwise.

Rather than barking, biting, or sniffing, the Siberian Husky's role was more therapeutic. One of Arctic's assignments: hanging out with the kids at a local middle school. They didn’t even get to say goodbye before his service was terminated.
